title: The charm of Edinburgh :
author: Hyatt, Alfred Henry.
snippet: And as Mad Mag was well-looking in a bold, gusty way, though burnt so brown that her china-blue eyes made holes in her face, Knifer Jackson rather liked to be seen out of doors with his wife on Sunday afternoons. They went down the length of the Pleasance, disappeared into a close, came out among the respectable houses in Arthur Street, and so downhill into the Queen's Park. There, as was customary, they went arm in arm.

title: Solved Mysteries; or, Revelations of a City Detective
author: Macgovan, James.
snippet: Without showing that I was anything but satisfied with the information I had received, I took leave of the pair, and went down to Arthur Street, and found out the house in which they had formerly lived with the bookfolder as a lodger. My object was to find out if any of the neighbours had noticed the bookfolder leaving, or had heard her speak of her intended destination.

title: Brought to Bay; or, Experiences of a City Detective
author: Macgovan, James.
snippet: All this I could believe, even if I had only Holman's case to judge by. He ascended a common stair in Arthur Street with a letter enclosed in a blue envelope in his hand. He ought to have gone to the top, but he did not.

title: Cleg Kelly, Arab of the City
author: Crockett, Samuel Rutherford.
snippet: in a race. And many had been the Arthur Street urchins who had suffered a sore skin and a night in the cells after being taken in dire offence. So ' the Warrior ' they called him, for an all-sufficient name.

title: Solved Mysteries; or, Revelations of a City Detective
author: Macgovan, James.
snippet: " Turn up your books, and see if the June entries include the death of one Agnes Hunter, Arthur Street," was my magnificent command ; Mr Cowan obeyed, with a quiet grin, and soon stopped, '.vith the exclamation— "All right: here it is—'Agnes Hunter, aged thirty-one. Present—Thomas Hun'er.

title: Fishers of men,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: And as Mad Mag was well-looking in a bold, gusty way, though burnt so brown that her china-blue eyes made holes in her face, Knifer Jackson rather liked to be seen out of doors with his wife on Sunday afternoons. They went down the length of the pleasance, disappeared into a close, came out among the respectable houses in Arthur Street, and so down hill into the Queen's Park. There, as was customary, they went arm in arm.

title: Solved Mysteries; or, Revelations of a City Detective
author: Macgovan, James.
snippet: So far as I could see, nothing was to be gained and much was to be expended by putting the bookfolder out of the way. After leaving Arthur Street, and while still studying these points, it struck me as quite an easy matter to test the truth of the statements made by those neighbours without going near the cobbler at all, who, I felt assured, would have lied through a brick wall. The office of the registrar was not far off, and thither I turned with quickened interest.

title: Brought to Bay; or, Experiences of a City Detective
author: Macgovan, James.
snippet: Yet even at this, the last moment, it seemed as if he were only to accomplish the task with a fight. As he passed along Richmond Street, he got a quick glimpse of the man whose watch he had stolen ! A glimpse—nothing more ; for he was through the close towards Arthur Street like the wind. Down—down ! The stair at last! Up he fnounted, found the door, rang the bell, and the letter was delivered ! But now he felt at what a cost the whole had been accomplished.

title: Solved Mysteries; or, Revelations of a City Detective
author: Macgovan, James.
snippet: His name's Hunter, and he lives in the Potterrow. He was in Arthur Street when my sister lodged wi' him, and I wad like to ken what he flittit for if it wasna to escape justice? "

title: Solved Mysteries; or, Revelations of a City Detective
author: Macgovan, James.
snippet: " Oh, here it is—Mrs Hunter, Arthur Street," he said, reading from the book. " Heart disease—two hours illness."

title: Cleg Kelly, Arab of the City
author: Crockett, Samuel Rutherford.
snippet: The Drabble was found trying to steal collars off a clothes-line at the back of Arthur Street. Cleg Kelly had no objections to this feat.
